FILE: cm359365v11.0.txt
DYAD: MOLDOVA/MOLDAVIA - RUSSIA/USSR
RIVALRY: RIV959
DISPUTE(S): MID3558 MID4051 

PS-NOTES:

PS-LAST-CHANGED: 20180911
LS-LAST-CHECKED: 20180911

Territorial-Maritime-Boundary Issues Variables

MID3558 

TERRMID: MID3558 3 -- not territory 
TERRMID-CER: MID3558 1 -- certain 
TERRMID-NOTES: MID3558 from Gibler 2018, Russia was displeased that Moldova was becoming closer to Romania, became threatened, and deployed troops to Moldova. Fighting ensued, but remained relatively low-level. Coded not territory because no boundary was being disputed.

TERRLINK: MID3558 3 -- not third party link to territory 
TERRLINK-CER: MID3558 1 -- certain 
TERRLINK-NOTES:

MID4051 

TERRMID: MID4051 3 -- not territory 
TERRMID-CER: MID4051 1 -- certain 
TERRMID-NOTES: MID4051 from Gibler 2018, Romania protested when Russia conducted military exercises that constituted a violation of a previous agreement between the countries. Coded not territory because no boundary was being disputed. 

TERRLINK: MID4051 3 -- not third party link to territory 
TERRLINK-CER: MID4051 1 -- certain

COUPMID-CER: MID4051 1 -- certain 
COUPMID-NOTES:

COUPLINK-NOTES: 

MID3 1993-2001:

MID4051
rivalry=359365 nationa=RUSSIA/USSR nationb=MOLDOVA MID4051 19930215-19930215 
 revtype1a=NOT APPLICABLE revtype2a=NOT APPLICABLE fatala=NONE fatalpa=0 lhosta=DISPLAY OF FORCE 
 revtype1b=POLICY revtype2b=NOT APPLICABLE fatalb=NONE fatalpb=0
lhostb=NO MILITARIZED ACTION 

Russia's 14th army has been stationed in Moldova since before the collapse of the Soviet Union. These troops participated in exercises on February 15, 1993. Moldova lodged an official protest. First and last day of dispute was on 2/15/1993.

RIVNOTES: 

NARRATIVE-CM:
Moldova declared its independence from the Soviet Union on August 27, 1991. Moldovan troops and Trans-Dnestr rebels engaged in military hostilities beginning on December 13, 1991. Russian troops intervened in support of the ethnic Russians in the Trans-Dnestr region. The foreign ministers of Russia, Ukraine, and Romania jointly appealed for a ceasefire on March 23, 1992. President Mircea Snegur of Moldova declared a state-of-emergency on March 28, 1992. Moldovan troops attacked Trans-Dnestr rebels near Bendery on April 1, 1992, resulting in the deaths of 18 individuals. The foreign ministers of Russia, Ukraine, and Romania mediated the signing of a ceasefire agreement in Kishinev on April 6-7, 1992. On April 17, 1992, Russia, Ukraine, Romania, and Moldova established a 160-member military observation commission to monitor the ceasefire. The Moldovan government and Trans Dnestr rebels agreed to a Russian-mediated ceasefire that went into effect on July 7, 1992. Moldova and Russia agreed on June 21, 1992 to deploy a joint peacekeeping force in the Trans-Dnestr region. Some 1,000 individuals were killed in the conflict from 1991 to 1992. The *Moldovan Joint Force* (MJF), which consisted of some 4,000 peacekeeping troops from Russia, Moldova, and Trans Dnestr, was deployed on August 1, 1992. Some 12 members of the MJF were killed in 1992 and 1993. Russia began mediation regarding the Trans Dnestr region on March 17, 1994. Moldovan government and Trans Dnestr representatives signed the *Memorandum on the Basis for Normalization of Relations between the Republic of Moldova and Trans Dnestr* in Moscow on May 8, 1997. The leaders of Moldova, Ukraine, and Russia met in Kiev on November 27-28, 1998 for negotiations regarding the Trans Dnestr region.

SOURCES-CM: 
Allock et al., 1992, 44-48; *Associated Press* (AP), November 12, 1999; Banks and Muller, 1998, 612-617; Bercovitch and Jackson, 1997, 253-254; *Keesing*, April 1992; *Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty *(RFE/RL), March 1, 1994, March 10, 1994, March 21, 1994, July 29, 1994; *Reuters*, November 10, 1998, November 9, 1999.


NARRATIVE-CR:

SOURCES-CR:

SOURCES: Gibler, D.M. 2018. Militarized Interstate Dispute Narratives, 1816-2010. Langham, MD: Rowman and Littlefield.
